column1: Byblos is located about 42 km (26 mi) north of Beirut. It is attractive to archaeologists because of the successive layers of debris resulting from centuries of human habitation. It was first excavated by Ernest Renan in 1860
column2: as published in his Mission de Ph√©nicie (1865‚Äì1874)
column3: then by Pierre Montet from 1921 until 1924
column4: followed by Maurice Dunand from 1925 over a period of forty years. Renan's expedition was to "provide the evidence that the city did not move and that Gebeil is Byblos"The site first appears to have been settled during the Pre-Pottery Neolithic B period
column5: approximately 8800 to 7000 BC. Neolithic remains of some buildings can be observed at the site. According to the writer Philo of Byblos (quoting Sanchuniathon
column7: Byblos had the reputation of being the oldest city in the world
column8: founded by Cronus.  During the 3rd millennium BC
column9: the first signs of a town can be observed
column10: with the remains of well-built houses of uniform size.  This was the period when the Canaanite civilization began to develop.

column1: Jacques Cauvin published studies of flint tools from the stratified Neolithic and Chalcolithic sites in 1962. Remains of humans found in Chalcolithic burials have been published by Henri Victor Vallois in 1937. Tombs from this era were discussed by Emir Maurice Chehab in 1950. Early pottery found at the tell was published by E.S. Boynton in 1960 with further studies by R. Erich in 1954 and Van Liere and Henri de Contenson in 1964.
Prehistoric settlements at Byblos were divided up by Dunand into the following five periods
column2: which were recently expanded and re-calibrated by Yosef Garfinkel to correlate with Tell es-Sultan (Jericho):

column1: Early Neolithic (Early Phase) corresponding to the Pre-Pottery Neolithic B (PPNB) of Jericho
column2: represented by plastered floors and naviforme technology
column3: dated between 8800 and 7000 BC;

column1: Early Neolithic (Late Phase) corresponding to the PNA of Tell es-Sultan (Jericho) IX (also Yarmukian) between 6400 and 5800 BC represented by pottery
column2: sickle blades
column3: figurines and small points

column1: Middle Neolithic corresponding to the PNB of Tell es-Sultan (Jericho) VIII and represented by pottery
column2: dated between 5800 and 5300 BC;

column1: Late Neolithic corresponding to the Middle Chalcolithic of Beth Shean and represented by pottery
column2: stone vessels
column3: silos

column1: Early Chalcolithic corresponding to the Late Chalcolithic of Ghassulian
column2: represented by jar burials
column3: pierced flint
column5: dated to between 4500 and 3600 BC and

column1: Late Chalcolithic corresponding to the Early Bronze Age
column2: represented by architecture and cylinder seal impressions
column3: dated to between 3600 and 3100 BC.The Early Neolithic was a later settlement than others in the Beqaa Valley such as Labweh and Ard Tlaili. It was located on the seaward slope of the larger of the two hills that used to compose ancient Byblos
column4: with a watered valley in between.The original site spread down into the valley and covered an area of 1.2 ha (3.0 acres) providing fertile soils and a protected landing place for boats. Dunand discovered around twenty houses although some of the settlement was suggested to have been lost to the sea
column5: robbed or destroyed. Dwellings were rectangular with plastered floors
column6: pottery was usually Dark faced burnished ware with some shell impressions.The Middle Neolithic was a smaller settlement of no more than 0.15 ha (0.37 acres) adjacent to the older site. The pottery was more developed with red washes and more varied forms and elaborate decorations
column7: buildings were poorer with unplastered floors.

column1: The Late Neolithic period showed development from the middle in building design
column2: a wider range of more developed flint tools and a far larger variety of pottery with fabrication including silica. The Late Chalcolithic featured developments of "Canaanean blades" and fan scrapers. Adult burials in jars started to appear along with metal in the form of one copper hook
column3: found in a jar. Some jars were lined with white plaster that was applied and self-hardened after firing. Copper appeared more frequently in the Late Chalcolithic period along with multiple burials in tombs and jar handles with impressed signs. Early Bronze Age remains were characterized by the development of Byblos combed ware and a lithic assemblage studied by Jacques Cauvin.According to Lorenzo Nigro
column4: Byblos moved from being a fishermen's village to its earlier urban form at the beginning of the third millennium BC. Fragments attributed to the semi-legendary pre-Homeric Phoenician priest Sanchuniathon say Byblos was the first city erected in Phoenicia and was established by the god Cronus. (Cronus was considered the nearest equivalent to the Canaanite Baal or Baal Hammon in the syncretizing system used by the ancient Greeks and Romans.)

column1: Watson Mills and Roger Bullard suggest that during the Old Kingdom of Egypt
column2: Byblos was virtually an Egyptian colony. The growing city was evidently a wealthy one and seems to have been an ally (among "those who are on his waters") of Egypt for many centuries. First Dynasty tombs used timbers from Byblos. One of the oldest Egyptian words for an oceangoing boat was "Byblos ship".  Archaeologists have recovered Egyptian-made artifacts as old as a vessel fragment bearing the name of the Second dynasty ruler Khasekhemwy
column3: although this "may easily have reached Byblos through trade and/or at a later period". Objects have been found at Byblos naming the 13th Dynasty Egyptian king Neferhotep I
column4: and the rulers of Byblos maintained close relationships with the New Kingdom pharaohs of Ancient Egypt.

column2: the Amarna letters include 60 letters from Rib-Hadda and his successor Ili-Rapih who were rulers of Byblos
column3: writing to the Egyptian government. This is mainly due to Rib-Hadda's constant pleas for military assistance from Akhenaten. They also deal with the conquest of neighboring city-states by the Habiru.

column1: It appears Egyptian contact peaked during the 19th dynasty
column2: only to decline during the 20th and 21st dynasties. In addition
column3: when the New Kingdom collapsed in the 11th century BC
column4: Byblos ceased being a colony and became the foremost city of Phoenicia.  Although the archaeological evidence seems to indicate a brief resurgence during the 22nd and 23rd dynasties
column5: it is clear after the Third Intermediate Period the Egyptians started favoring Tyre and Sidon instead of Byblos.Archaeological evidence at Byblos
column6: particularly the five Byblian royal inscriptions dating back to around 1200‚Äì1000 BC
column7: shows existence of a Phoenician alphabet of twenty-two characters; an important example is the Ahiram sarcophagus. The use of the alphabet was spread by Phoenician merchants through their maritime trade into parts of North Africa and Europe. One of the most important monuments of this period is the Temple of the Obelisks
column8: dedicated to the Canaanite war god Resheph
column9: but this had fallen into ruins by the time of Alexander the Great.

column2: Sibittibaal of Byblos became tributary to Tiglath-Pileser III in 738 BC

column5: the king of Byblos was Urumilki.  Byblos was also subject to Assyrian kings Esarhaddon (r. 681‚Äì669 BC) and Ashurbanipal (r. 668‚Äì627 BC)
column6: under its own kings Milkiasaph and Yehawmelek.

column2: Byblos was the fourth of four Phoenician vassal kingdoms established by the Persians; the first three being Sidon

column1: Hellenistic rule came with the arrival of Alexander the Great in the area in 332 BC. Coinage was in use
column2: and there is abundant evidence of continued trade with other Mediterranean countries.
the temple of Resheph was elaborately rebuilt
column3: and the city
column4: though smaller than its neighbours such as Tyre and Sidon
column5: was a center for the cult of Adonis. In the 3rd century
column6: a small but impressive theater was constructed.  With the rise of Christianity
column7: a bishopric was established in Byblos
column8: and the town grew rapidly.  Although a Sasanian colony is known to have been established in the region following the early Muslim conquests of 636
column9: there is little archaeological evidence for it. Trade with Europe effectively dried up
column10: and it was not until the coming of the First Crusade in 1098 that prosperity returned to Byblos

column1: In the 12th and 13th century Byblos became part of the County of Tripoli
column2: a Crusader state connected to
column3: but largely independent from
column4: the Crusader Kingdom of Jerusalem. As Gibelet or Giblet
column5: it came under the rule of the Genoese Embriaco family
column6: who created for themselves  the Lordship of Gibelet. Their residence
column9: served as an important military base for the Crusaders. The remains of the castle are among the most impressive architectural structures now visible in the town centre. The town was taken by Saladin in 1187
column12: but it remained in the possession of the Embriacos until around 1300. Having voluntarily surrendered to the Mamluks
column13: the city was relatively spared from looting following its capture. Its fortifications were subsequently restored. From 1516 until 1918
column14: the town and the whole region became part of the Ottoman Empire.

column1: Byblos and all of Lebanon was placed under French Mandate from 1920 until 1943 when Lebanon achieved independence.

The 2006 Lebanon War negatively affected the ancient city by covering its harbor and town walls with an oil slick that was the result of an oil spill from a nearby power-plant.  This however has been cleared and the coastal area has since then become a destination for beach goers
column2: especially in the late spring and throughout the summer season.
mostly Maronites

column5: and Greek Catholics. There is also a minority of Shia Muslims. It is said that the city of Bint Jbeil ("Daughter of Byblos") in southern Lebanon was founded by those Shia Muslims. Byblos has three representatives in the Parliament of Lebanon: two Maronites and one Shia.

column1: Byblos is home to the professional schools of the Lebanese American University (LAU). The LAU Byblos Campus houses the Medical School

column5: which offers the only Pharm.D. Program outside the United States accredited by the Accreditation Council for Pharmacy Education (ACPE)
column7: and the School of Arts and Sciences. The Campus is situated on a hill overlooking the city and the Mediterranean Sea.

column1: Byblos is re-emerging as an upscale touristic hub.  With its ancient port

column5: sandy beaches and the picturesque mountains that surround it make it an ideal tourist destination. The city is known for its fish restaurants

column1: Medieval city wallThe old medieval part of Byblos is surrounded by walls running about 270m from east to west and 200m from north to south.
Byblos Castle was built by the Crusaders in the 12th century. It is located in the archaeological site near the port.

St John the Baptist ChurchWork on the church started during the Crusades in 1116. It was considered a cathedral and was partially destroyed during an earthquake in 1176 AD. When Islamic forces captured the city
column2: it was transformed into a set of stables. It was later given to the Maronites as a gift by Prince Youssef Chehab of Lebanon in the mid-1700s
column3: after they aided him in capturing the city.
